learning.title: Defaults, Choice Overload, and Nudge Ethics

questions.promptMd: Which pattern BEST aligns with nudge ethics?

answers.contentMd: Transparent default with clear rationale, easy opt‑out, and documentation of intent
answers.feedbackMd: Meets transparency, reversibility, and autonomy criteria.

answers.contentMd: Hidden default that requires support to change
Ten similar options to avoid bias

questions.promptMd: True or False: Disclosing nudge intent reduces its effectiveness.

answers.feedbackMd: Transparent nudges can remain effective and build trust.
Correct. Clarity increases legitimacy and often adoption.

questions.promptMd: Which intervention MOST reduces choice overload?

answers.contentMd: Curate 2–3 options mapped to distinct needs with a recommended option
Show all 20 options with equal prominence

questions.promptMd: True or False: It’s ethical to design defaults that are opt‑out but extremely inconvenient to reverse if the outcome is beneficial.

answers.feedbackMd: Inconvenient opt‑outs violate autonomy and can erode trust.
Correct. Reversibility and convenience are ethical requirements.
